additionalTextInformation.text:
'The present composition is based on Albrecht Dürer's woodcut Ecce Homo of circa 1498 and was possibly part of a series of altarpieces produced between 1520 and 1525 for the Stiftskirche in Halle, which included scenes from the Passion and were painted after designs by Lucas Cranach the Elder.'

[Christie's online database: https://www.christies.com/lotfinder/lot/studio-of-lucas-cranach-the-elder-4428315-details.aspx?; accessed 29.06.2020]

pageContext.description:
Christ and Pilate are shown standing at the top of stairs at the left and appear to be involved in a deep discussion with a bearded man in the foreground, wearing a long blue cape over a yellow robe. Christ is represented with the crown of thorns on his head and covered in blood. He is clad only in a loincloth and a red cloak. The woman behind him pulls back this cloak to reveal his wounds, while further bearded gentleman observes events from behind with little compassion. At the right the stage-like architectural setting ends to reveal a small strip of mountainous landscape, a solitary tree and a distant town. A crowd of angry Jews and soldiers spills into the pictorial space from this direction.
[cda 2020]

pageContext.inscription: Hebrew lettering on the hem of the man, wearing a blue gown and yellow robe, prominently positioned in the foreground in dialogue with Christ
